appendix.title: Core tasks
appendix.para: This appendix contains a reference of all core tasks, i.e. all tasks that are needed to build a basic project.

This reference lists the tasks alphabetically by the name of the classes that implement the tasks. So if you are searching for the reference to the <copy> tag, for example, you will want to look at the reference of CopyTask.

sect1.title: AdhocTaskdefTask
sect1.para: The AdhocTaskdefTask allows you to define a task within your build file.
Note that you should use <![CDATA[ ... ]]> so that you don't have to quote entities within your <adhoc-task></adhoc-task> tags.

row.entry: Name of XML tag that will represent this task.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<target name="main"
        description="==>test AdhocTask ">
		
		<adhoc-task name="foo"><![CDATA[
			class FooTest extends Task {
				private $bar;
				
				function setBar($bar) {
					$this->bar = $bar;
				}
				
				function main() {
					$this->log("In FooTest: " . $this->bar);
				}
			}
		]]></adhoc-task>
	
		<foo bar="B.L.I.N.G"/>
</target>

sect1.title: AdhocTypedefTask
sect1.para: The AdhocTypedefTask allows you to define a datatype within your build file.
Note that you should use <![CDATA[ ... ]]> so that you don't have to quote entities within your <adhoc-type></adhoc-type> tags.

row.entry: Name of XML tag that will represent this datatype..

sect2.title: Example
sect2.programlisting:
<target name="main"
        description="==>test AdhocType">
		
		<adhoc-type name="dsn"><![CDATA[
			class CreoleDSN extends DataType {
				private $url;
				
				function setUrl($url) {
					$this->url = $url;
				}
				
				function getUrl() {
  				return $this->url;
				}				
			}
		]]></adhoc-type>

     <!-- creole-sql task doesn't exist; just an example -->
     <creole-sql file="test.sql">
       <dsn url="mysql://root@localhost/test"/>
		</creole-sql>

</target>

sect1.title: AppendTask
sect1.para: The Append Task appends text or contents of files to a specified file.

In the example above, AppendTask is reading a filename from book/PhingGuide.book, processing the file contents with XSLT, and then appending the result to the file located at ${process.outputfile}. This is a real example from the build file used to generate this book!

row.entry: Path of file to which text should be appended.
Path to file that should be appended to destFile.
Some literal text to append to file.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <append destFile="${process.outputfile}"> <filterchain> <xsltfilter style="${process.stylesheet}"> <param name="mode" expression="${process.xslt.mode}"/> </xsltfilter> </filterchain> <filelist dir="book/" listfile="book/PhingGuide.book"/> </append>

sect1.title: ApplyTask
sect1.para: Applies a system command on each resource of the specified resource collection.
When the os attribute is specified, then the command is only executed when run on one of the specified operating systems.
The files of a number of Resource Collections – including but not restricted to FileSets or FileLists – are passed as arguments to the system command.

row.entry: The command to execute without any command line arguments.
The directory the command is to be executed in.
Only execute if the property contains specified text.
Escape shell metacharacters before execution. Setting this to true will enable the escape precaution.
Whether to use PHP's passthru() function instead of exec().
Whether to spawn unix programs to the background, redirecting stdout.
Property name to set return value to from the execution.
Property name to set output value to from the execution.
Whether to check the return code of the execution, throws a BuildException when returncode != 0.
Whether output (and error) should be appended to or overwrite an existing file. If you set parallel to false, you will probably want to set this one to true.
Run the command only once, appending all files as arguments. If false, command will be executed once for every file.

Whether source file name(s) should be added to the end of command-line automatically. If you need to place it somewhere different, use a nested <srcfile> element between your <arg> elements to mark the insertion point.
Whether the command(s) to be executed are spawned as background process. If a command is spawned, its output will not be logged by Phing.
Whether the filenames should be passed on the command line as relative pathnames (relative to the base directory of the corresponding fileset/list for source files).
Whether the file names should be passed with forward slashes even if the operating system requires other file separator.
Limit the amount of parallelism by passing at most this many sourcefiles at once. Set it to <= 0 for unlimited.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- Invokes somecommand arg1 SOURCEFILENAME arg2 for each file in /tmp --> <apply executable="somecommand" parallel="false"> <arg value="arg1"/> <srcfile/> <arg value="arg2"/> <fileset dir="/tmp"/> </apply>
<!-- List all the .conf files of "/etc" to the "out.log" file. --> <apply executable="ls" output="/tmp/out.log" append="true" > <arg value="-alh" /> <fileset dir="/etc" > <include name="*.conf" /> </fileset> </apply>

row.entry: A single command-line argument; can contain space characters.
A string that will be treated as a path-like string as a single command-line argument; you can use ; or : as path separators and Ant will convert it to the platform's local conventions.
A space-delimited list of command-line arguments.

sect1.title: AvailableTask
sect1.para: Available Task tests if a resource/file is set and sets a certain property to a certain value if it exists.

Here, AvailableTask first checks for the existance of either file or directory named test.txt in /tmp. Then, it checks for the directory foo in /home and then for the file or directory bar in /home/foo. If /tmp/test.txt is found, the property test_txt_exists is set to "Yes", if /home/foo is found and a directory, properties.yetanother is set to "true" (default). If /home/foo/bar exists, AvailableTask will set foo.bar to "Well, yes". And last it checks if extension foo is loaded, so the property foo.ext.loaded is set to "true" (default). k
NB: the Available task can also be used as a condition, see .

row.entry: Name of the property that is to be set.
The value the property is to be set to.
Path of the resource to look for.
Name of the extension to look for.
Determines if AvailableTask should look for a file or a directory at the position set by file. If empty, it checks for either file or directory.
The path to use when looking up file.
Whether to dereference symbolic links when looking up file.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<available file="/tmp/test.txt" property="test_txt_exists" value="Yes"/>
<available file="/home/foo" type="dir" property="properties.yetanother" />
<available file="/home/foo/bar" property="foo.bar" value="Well, yes" />

sect1.title: ChmodTask
sect1.para: Sets the mode of a file or directory.
For more informations, see chmod in the PHP Manual.

row.entry: The name of the file or directory. You either have to specify this attribute, or use a fileset.
The new mode (octal) for the file. Specified in octal, even if the first digit is not a '0'.
Set quiet mode, which suppresses warnings if chmod() fails
This flag means 'note errors to the output, but keep going'
Give more information in error message in case of a failure

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <chmod file="test.txt" mode="0755" /> <chmod file="/home/test" mode="0775" /> <chmod file="/home/test/mine.txt" mode="0500" verbose="true" />

sect1.title: ChownTask
sect1.para: Changes the owner of a file or directory.

row.entry: The name of the file or directory. You either have to specify this attribute, or use a fileset.
The new owner of the file. Can contain a username and a groupname, separated by a dot.
The new group owner of the file.
Set quiet mode, which suppresses warnings if chmod() fails
This flag means 'note errors to the output, but keep going'
Give more information in error message in case of a failure

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <chown file="my-file.txt" user="foo" /> <chown file="my-file.txt" user="username.groupname" /> <chown file="/home/test/my-directory" user="bar" /> <chown file="/home/test/my-file.txt" user="foo" verbose="true" failonerror="false" />

sect1.title: ConditionTask
sect1.para: Sets a property if a certain condition holds true - this is a generalization of and .

If the condition holds true, the property value is set to true by default; otherwise, the property is not set. You can set the value to something other than the default by specifying the value attribute.
Conditions are specified as nested elements, you must specify exactly one condition - see for a complete list of nested elements.

row.entry: The name of the property to set.
The value to set the property to. Defaults to "true".

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <condition property="isMacOrWindows"> <or> <os family="mac"/> <os family="windows"/> </or> </condition>

sect1.title: CopyTask
sect1.para: Copies files or directories. Files are only copied if the source file is newer than the destination file, or when the destination file does not exist. It is possible to explictly overwrite existing files.
CopyTask does not allow self copying, i.e. copying a file to the same name for security reasons.

entry.para: The destination the file is to be written to. tofile specifies a full filename. If you only want to specify a directory to copy to, use todir.
Either this or the todir attribute is required.

row.entry: The directory the file is to be copied to. The file will have the same name of the source file. If you want to specify a different name, use tofile. The directory must exist.
Overwrite existing files even if the destination files are newer.
If set to true, the new file will have the same mtime as the old one.
If set to true, the new file (and directory) will have the same permissions as the old one. The mode specified for directory creation will be ignored.
If set to true, also empty directories are copied.
If set to true, halts the build when errors are encountered.

note.para: No automatic exapnsion of symbolic links
By default, CopyTask does not expand / dereference symbolic links, and will simply copy the link itself. To enable dereferencing, set expandsymboliclinks to true in the <fileset> tag.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.para: On the one hand, CopyTask can be used to copy file by file:
sect2.programlisting: <copy file="somefile.txt" tofile="/tmp/anotherfile.bak" overwrite="true"/>
sect2.para: Additionally, CopyTask supports Filesets, i.e. you can easily include/exclude one or more files. For more information, see -- pay particular attention to the defaultexcludes attribute. and are also supported by CopyTask, so you can do almost everything that needs processing the content of the files or the filename.
sect2.programlisting: <copy todir="/tmp/backup" > <fileset dir="."> <include name="**/*.txt" /> <include name="**/*.doc" /> <include name="**/*.swx" /> </fileset> <filelist dir="." files="test.html"/> </copy>
<copy todir="build" > <fileset defaultexcludes="false" expandsymboliclinks="true" dir="."> <include name="**/*.php" /> </fileset> </copy>

sect1.title: CvsTask
sect1.para: Allows rudimentary interfacing with the CVS versioning system.
As you would expect, this lets you do pretty much anything with CVS. The CvsTask calls ExecTask which actually does the command execution.

row.entry: The root directory on the CVS server
Path to the rsh to execute
Port ion the server to use
Name of file with CVS passwords
The directory where checked out files should be placed
The tag of the package/module to operate upon
Use the most recent revision no later than the given date
If true, only report changes don't actually do anything
Stop the build process if the command returns any errors
If true, turns on compression using default (3) compression level
File to which output should be written
File to which error output should be written
Optional command line to be given to the CVS task

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <cvs cvsRoot=":pserver:guest@cvs.tigris.org:/cvs" module="phing" dest="${ws.dir}"/>
sect2.para: or, using the optional command line arguments:
sect2.programlisting: <cvs output="patch" command="-q diff -u -N" />

sect1.title: CvsPassTask
sect1.para: This lets you create your own cvs password file -- i.e. this is necessary if you want to provide a password in your build file.
If no password file is specified the default location .cvspass in users home directory is used.

row.entry: The root directory on the CVS server
Password file to add password to

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- create a password file --> <cvspass cvsRoot=":pserver:guest@cvs.tigris.org:/cvs" passfile="cvspass" password="guest"/>
<!-- use the just-created password file --> <cvs cvsRoot=":pserver:guest@cvs.tigris.org:/cvs" module="phing" passFile="cvspass" />

sect1.title: DeleteTask
sect1.para: Deletes a file or directory, or set of files defined by a fileset. See for information on Filesets.

row.entry: The file that is to be deleted. You either have to specify this attribute, dir, or use a fileset.
The directory that is to be deleted. You either have to specify this attribute, file, or use a fileset.
Used to force listing of all names of deleted files.

entry.para: If the file does not exist, do not display a diagnostic message or modify the exit status to reflect an error. This means that if a file or directory cannot be deleted, then no error is reported.
This setting emulates the -f option to the Unix rm command. Default is false meaning things are verbose

row.entry: If this attribute is set to true, DeleteTask will verbose on errors but the build process will not be stopped.
Determines if empty directories are also to be deleted.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- Delete a specific file --> <delete file="/tmp/foo.bar" />
<!-- Delete a directory --> <delete dir="/tmp/darl" includeemptydirs="true" verbose="true" failonerror="true" />
<!-- Delete using a fileset --> <delete> <fileset dir="/tmp"> <include name="*.bar" /> </fileset> </delete>

sect1.title: EchoTask
sect1.para: Echoes a message to the current loggers and listeners which means standard out unless overridden. A level can be specified, which controls at what logging level the message is filtered at.
The task can also echo to a file, in which case the option to append rather than overwrite the file is available, and the level option is ignored
Additionally, the task can echo the contents of a nested fileset element.

row.entry: The string that is to be send to the output.
The file to write the message to.
Control the level at which this message is reported. One of error, warning, info, verbose, debug.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<echo msg="Phing rocks!" />
<echo message="Binarycloud, too." />
<echo>And don't forget Propel.</echo>
<echo file="test.txt" append="false">This is a test message</echo>

sect1.title: ExecTask
sect1.para: Executes a shell command. You can use this to quickly add a new command to Phing. However, if you want to use this regularly, you should think about writing a Task for it.

row.entry: The command that is to be executed.
The command to execute without any command line arguments.
The directory the command is to be executed in.
Redirected to stdout, unless passthru is set to true.
Only execute if the property contains specified text.
By default, we escape shell metacharacters before executing. Setting this to false will disable this precaution.
Whether to use PHP's passthru() function instead of exec().
Whether to log returned output as MSG_INFO instead of MSG_VERBOSE.
Whether to spawn unix programs to the background, redirecting stdout.
Property name to set return value to from exec() call.
Property name to set output value to from exec() call.
Whether to check the return code of the program, throws a BuildException when returncode != 0.
Control the level at which status messages are reported. One of error, warning, info, verbose, debug.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- List the contents of "/home". --> <exec command="ls -l" dir="/home" />
<!-- Start the make process in "/usr/src/php-4.0". --> <exec command="make" dir="/usr/src/php-4.0" />
<!-- List the contents of "/tmp" out to a file. --> <exec command="ls -l /tmp > foo.out" escape="false" />

row.entry: A single command-line argument; can contain space characters. To pass an empty argument, enclose two double quotes in single quotes ('""').
A string that will be treated as a path-like string as a single command-line argument; you can use ; or : as path separators and Ant will convert it to the platform's local conventions.
A space-delimited list of command-line arguments.

sect1.title: FailTask
sect1.para: Causes the current build script execution to fail and the script to exit with an (optional) error message.

row.entry: The message to display (reason for script abort).
Name of property that must be set for script to exit.
Name of property that must not be set in order for script to exit.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- Exit w/ message --> <fail message="Failed for some reason!" />
<!-- Exit if ${errorprop} is defined --> <fail if="errorprop" message="Detected error!" />
<!-- Exit unless ${dontfail} prop is defined. --> <fail unless="dontfail" message="Detected error!" />

sect1.title: ForeachTask
sect1.para: The foreach task iterates over a list, a list of filesets, or both. If both, list and filesets, are specified, the list will be evaluated first. Nested filesets are evaluated in the order they appear in the task.

row.entry: The list of values to process, with the delimiter character, indicated by the "delimiter" attribute, separating each value.
The target to call for each token, passing the token as the parameter with the name indicated by the "param" attribute.
The name of the parameter to pass the tokens in as to the target.
The name of the absolute pathparameter to pass the tokens in as to the target (used while processing nested filesets).
The delimiter string that separates the values in the "list" parameter. The default is ",".

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- loop through languages, and call buildlang task with setted param --> <property name="languages" value="en,fr,de" /> <foreach list="${languages}" param="lang" target="buildlang" />
<!-- loop through files, and call subtask task with set param and absparam --> <foreach param="filename" absparam="absfilename" target="subtask"> <fileset dir="."> <include name="*.php"/> </fileset> </foreach>

sect1.title: IfTask
sect1.para: Perform some tasks based on whether a given condition holds true or not.
This task doesn't have any attributes, the condition to test is specified by a nested element - see the for a complete list of nested elements.
Just like the <condition> task, only a single condition can be specified - you combine them using <and> or <or> conditions.

In addition to the condition, you can specify three different child elements, <elseif> , <then> and <else> . All three subelements are optional. Both <then> and <else> must not be used more than once inside the if task. Both are containers for Phing tasks.

The <elseif> behaves exactly like an <if> except that it cannot contain the <else> element inside of it. You may specify as may of these as you like, and the order they are specified is the order they are evaluated in. If the condition on the <if> is false, then the first <elseif> who's conditional evaluates to true will be executed. The <else> will be executed only if the <if> and all <elseif> conditions are false.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <if> <equals arg1="${foo}" arg2="bar" /> <then> <echo message="The value of property foo is bar" /> </then> <else> <echo message="The value of property foo is not bar" /> </else> </if>

<if> <equals arg1="${foo}" arg2="bar" /> <then> <echo message="The value of property foo is 'bar'" /> </then>
<elseif> <equals arg1="${foo}" arg2="foo" /> <then> <echo message="The value of property foo is 'foo'" /> </then> </elseif>
<else> <echo message="The value of property foo is not 'foo' or 'bar'" /> </else> </if>

sect1.title: ImportTask
sect1.para: Imports another build file into the current project.
On execution it will read another Phing file into the same Project. Functionally it is nearly the same as copy and pasting the imported file onto the end of the importing file.

row.entry: If true, do not stop the build if the file does not exist.

sect2.title: Target Overriding
sect2.para: If a target in the main file is also present in at least one of the imported files, the one from the main file takes precedence.

So if I import for example a docs/build.xml file named builddocs, that contains a "docs" target, I can redefine it in my main buildfile and that is the one that will be called. This makes it easy to keep the same target name, so that the overriding target is still called by any other targets--in either the main or imported buildfile(s)--for which it is a dependency, with a different implementation. The target from docs/build.xml is made available by the name "builddocs.docs". This enables the new implementation to call the old target, thus enhancing it with tasks called before or after it.

sect2.title: Special Properties
sect2.para: Imported files are treated as they are present in the main buildfile. This makes it easy to understand, but it makes it impossible for them to reference files and resources relative to their path. Because of this, for every imported file, Phing adds a property that contains the path to the imported buildfile. With this path, the imported buildfile can keep resources and be able to reference them relative to its position.

So if I import for example a docs/build.xml file named builddocs, I can get its path as phing.file.builddocs, similarly to the phing.file property of the main buildfile. Additionally, the directory will be stored in phing.dir.builddocs.
Note that "builddocs" is not the filename, but the name attribute present in the imported project tag.
If import file does not have a name attribute, the phing.file.projectname and phing.dir.projectname properties will not be set.

sect2.title: Resolving Files Against the Imported File
sect2.para: Suppose your main build file called importing.xml imports a build file imported.xml , located anywhere on the file system, and imported.xml reads a set of properties from imported.properties :
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- importing.xml --> <project name="importing" basedir="." default="..."> <import file="${path_to_imported}/imported.xml"/> </project>
<!-- imported.xml --> <project name="imported" basedir="." default="..."> <property file="imported.properties"/> </project>
sect2.para: This snippet however will resolve imported.properties against the basedir of importing.xml , because the basedir of imported.xml is ignored by Phing. The right way to use imported.properties is:
sect2.programlisting: <!-- imported.xml --> <project name="imported" basedir="." default="..."> <property file="${phing.file.imported}/imported.properties"/> </project>
sect2.para: As explained above ${phing.file.imported} stores the full path of the build script, that defines the project called imported, (in short it stores the path to imported.xml) and ${phing.dir.imported} stores its directory. This technique also allows imported.xml to be used as a standalone file (without being imported in other project).

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <import file="path/to/build.xml"/> <import file="path/to/build.xml" optional="true"/>

sect1.title: IncludePathTask
sect1.para: Sets the PHP include_path configuration option for the duration of this phing run.

row.entry: Reference to a previously defined Path type

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <includepath classpath="new/path/here" /> <includepath classpath="path1:path2" />
<path id="project.class.path"> <pathelement dir="lib/"/> <pathelement dir="ext/"/> </paentry> <includepath classpathref="project.class.path" />

sect1.title: InputTask
sect1.para: The InputTask can be used to interactively set property values based on input from the console (or other Reader).

row.entry: The name of the property to set.
The default value to be set if no new value is provided.
The prompt character to follow prompt text.
Comma-separated list of valid choices the user must supply. If used, one of these options must be chosen.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- Getting string input --> <echo>HTML pages installing to: ${documentRoot}</echo> <echo>PHP classes installing to: ${servletDirectory}</echo>
<input propertyname="documentRoot">Web application document root</input> <input propertyname="servletDirectory" defaultValue="/usr/servlets" promptChar="?">PHP classes install dir</input>
<echo>HTML pages installed to ${documentRoot}</echo> <echo>PHP classes installed to ${servletDirectory}</echo>
<!-- Having the user choose from a set of valid choices --> <echo>Choose a valid option:</echo>
<input propertyname="optionsChoice" validargs="foo,bar,bob"> Which item would you like to use </input>

sect1.title: LoadFileTask
sect1.para: The LoadFileTask loads the contents of a (text) file into a single property.

row.entry: The name of the property to set.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <loadfile property="version" file="version.txt"/>

sect1.title: MkdirTask
sect1.para: Creates a directory, including any necessary but non-existent parent directories. Does nothing if the directory already exists.

row.entry: The directory that is to be created.
The mode to create the directory with.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- Create a temp directory --> <mkdir dir="/tmp/foo" />
<!-- Using mkdir with a property --> <mkdir dir="${dirs.install}/tmp" />

sect1.title: MoveTask
sect1.para: Moves a file or directory to a new file or directory. By default, the destination file is overwritten if it already exists. When overwrite is turned off, then files are only moved if the source file is newer than the destination file, or when the destination file does not exist.
Source files and directories are only deleted if the file or directory has been copied to the destination successfully.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- The following will move the file "somefile.txt" to "/tmp" and change its filename to "anotherfile.bak". It will overwrite an existing file. --> <move file="somefile.txt" tofile="/tmp/anotherfile.bak" overwrite="true"/>
<!-- This will move the "/tmp" directory to "/home/default/tmp", preserving the directory name. So the final name is "/home/default/tmp/tmp". Empty directories are also copied --> <move file="/tmp" todir="/home/default/tmp" includeemptydirs="true" />

sect2.title: Attributes and Nested Elements
sect2.para: For further documentation, see , since MoveTask only is a child of CopyTask and inherits all attributes.

sect1.title: PhingTask
sect1.para: This task calls another build file. You may specify the target that is to be called within the build file. Additionally, the <phing> Tag may contain <property> Tags (see ).

row.entry: If true, pass all properties to the new phing project.
If true, pass all references to the new phing project.

The directory to use as a base directory for the new phing project. Default is the current project's basedir, unless inheritall has been set to false, in which case it doesn't have a default value. This will override the basedir setting of the called project.
The build file to use. Defaults to "build.xml". This file is expected to be a filename relative to the dir attribute given.
The target of the new Phing project to execute. Default is the new project's default target.
If true, fail the build process when the called build fails

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- Call target "xslttest" from buildfile "alternativebuildfile.xml" --> <phing phingfile="alternativebuild.xml" inheritRefs="true" target="xslttest" />
<!-- Do a more complex call --> <phing phingfile="somebuild.xml" target="sometarget"> <property name="foo" value="bar" /> <property name="anotherone" value="32" /> </phing>

sect2.title: Base directory of the new project
sect2.para: The base directory of the new project is set dependant on the dir and the inheritAll attribute. This is important to keep in mind or else you might run into bugs in your build.xml's. The following table shows when which value is used:

row.entry: basedir of calling task (the build file containing the <phing> call.
basedir attribute of the <project> element of the new project

sect1.title: PhingCallTask
sect1.para: The PhingCallTask calls a target within the same Phing project.
A <phingcall> tag may contain <property> tags that define new properties. These properties are only set if properties of the same name have not been set outside the "phingcall" tag.

row.entry: The name of the target in the same project that is to be called.

note.para: Every <phingcall> tag creates a new local scope. Thus, any properties or other variables set inside that scope will cease to exist (or revert to their previous value) once the <phingcall> tag completes.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <target name="foo"> <phingcall target="bar"> <property name="property1" value="aaaaa" /> <property name="foo" value="baz" /> </phingcall> </target>
sect2.para: In the example above, the properties property1 and foo are defined and only accessible inside the called target.
sect2.programlisting: <target name="bar" depends="init"> <echo message="prop is ${property1} ${foo}" /> </target>

sect1.title: PhpEvalTask
sect1.para: With the PhpEvalTask, you can set a property to the results of evaluating a PHP expression or the result returned by a function/method call.

row.entry: The static class which contains function.
The name of the property to set with result of expression or function call. Note: if this attribute is set, the expression must return a value.
Control the level at which phplint reports status messages. One of error, warning, info, verbose, debug.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <php function="crypt" returnProperty="enc_passwd"> <param value="${auth.root_passwd}"/> </php>
<php expression="3 + 4" returnProperty="sum"/>
<php expression="echo 'test';">

sect1.title: PropertyTask
sect1.para: With PropertyTask, you can define user properties in your build file.

row.entry: Loads properties from the environment with the specified value as prefix. Thus if you specify environment="myenv" you will be able to access OS-specific environment variables via property names "myenv.PATH" or "myenv.TERM".
Whether to force override of existing value.
Used when properites are loaded from file. Prefix is applied to properties loaded from specified file. A "." is appended to the prefix if not specified.
A reference to a previously defined propeprty
If a reference cannot be found within the current project scope this attribute specifies a fallback project scope.

note.para: Important note about scope: when the <property> tag is called inside a <phingcall> tag, any properties are set in a new local scope. Thus, any properties or other variables set inside that scope will cease to exist (or revert to their previous value) once the parent <phingcall> tag completes.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<property name="strings.test" value="Harr harr, more power!" /> <echo message="${strings.test}" />
<property name="foo.bar" value="Yet another property..." /> <echo message="${foo.bar}" />
<property file="build.properties" />
<property environment="env" />
<property name="newproperty" value="Hello"> <filterchain> <replaceregexp> <regexp pattern="Hello" replace="World" ignoreCase="true"/> </replaceregexp> </filterchain> </property>

sect1.title: PropertyPromptTask
sect1.para: PropertyPromptTask is a simple task to read in user input into a property. If you need something more advanced, see the .

row.entry: The name of the Property to set.
The text to use for the prompt.
The character to use after the prompt.
A default value to use (if user just hits enter).
Whether existing property should be used if available. (This will result in user only being prompted if the propertyName property is not already set.)

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <propertyprompt propertyName="someprop" defaultValue="/var/www" promptText="Enter your web root" /> <echo>${someprop}</echo>

sect1.title: ReflexiveTask
sect1.para: The ReflexiveTask performs operations on files. It is essentially a convenient way to transform (using filter chains) files without copying them.

row.entry: A single file to be processed.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <reflexive> <fileset dir="."> <include pattern="*.html"> </fileset> <filterchain> <replaceregexp> <regexp pattern="\r(\n)" replace="\1"/> </replaceregexp> </filterchain> </reflexive>

sect1.title: ResolvePathTask
sect1.para: The ResolvePathTask turns a relative path into an absolute path, with respect to specified directory or the project basedir (if no dir attribute specified).

This task is useful for turning a user-defined relative path into an absolute path in cases where buildfiles will be called in different directories. Without this task, buildfiles lower in the directory tree would mis-interpret the user-defined relative paths.

row.entry: The file or directory path to resolve.
The base directory to use when resolving "file".
The name of the property to set with resolved (absolute) path.
Control the level at which status messages are reported. One of error, warning, info, verbose, debug.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<property name="relative_path" value="./dirname"/>
<resolvepath propertyName="absolute_path" file="${relative_path}"/>
<echo>Resolved [absolute] path: ${absolute_path}</echo>

sect1.title: TaskdefTask
sect1.para: With the TaskdefTask you can import a user task into your buildfile.

row.entry: The path to the class that defines the TaskClass.
Yes, unless the file attribute has been specified.
The name the task is available as after importing. If you specify "validate", for example, you can access the task imported here with <validate>.
Yes, unless the file attribute has been specified.
Name of the file to load definitions from.
The classpath to use when including classes. This is added to PHP's include_path.
Reference to classpath to use when including classes. This is added to PHP's include_path.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<!-- Includes the Task named "ValidateHTMLTask" and makes it available by <validatehtml> --> <taskdef classname="user.tasks.ValidateHTMLTask" name="validatehtml" />
<!-- Includes the Task "RebootTask" from "user/sometasks" somewhere inside the $PHP_CLASSPATH --> <taskdef classname="user.sometasks.RebootTask" name="reboot" />
<!-- Includes all tasks from the property file. Each line in the property file defines a task in the format: name=path.to.Task --> <taskdef file="/path/to/mytasks.properties" />
sect2.para: NB: Taskdef now supports the PEAR-style naming convention to define and load tasks:
sect2.programlisting: <taskdef name="sampletask" classname="Dir_Subdir_SampleTask"/>
sect2.para: will load class Dir_Subdir_SampleTask from file Dir/Subdir/SampleTask.php.

sect1.title: TouchTask
sect1.para: The TouchTask works like the Unix touch command: It sets the modtime of a file to a specific time. Default is the current time.

row.entry: The file which time is to be changed.
The date and time the mtime of the file is to be set to. The format is "MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM AM or PM"
The number of milliseconds since Midnight Jan 1 1970 (Unix epoche).

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<touch file="README.txt" millis="102134111" />
<touch file="COPYING.lib" datetime="10/10/1999 09:31 AM" />

sect1.title: TryCatchTask
sect1.para: This task is a wrapper task that lets you run tasks(s) when another set of tasks fails, mirroring PHP's try/catch functionality (with the addition of finally block)
The tasks inside of the try block will always be run. If one of them throws a BuildException, the following things can happen:

listitem.para: If there is no catch block, the exception will be passed to Phing.
If the property attribute has been set a property of that name will contain the message of the exception.
If there is a catch block, the nested tasks will be run.

sect1.para: If a finally block is present, the nested tasks will be run regardless of whether the tasks in the try block have thrown an exception or not.
This task was inspired by http://ant-contrib.sourceforge.net/tasks/tasks/trycatch.html.

row.entry: Name of a property that will receive the message of the exception that has been caught (if any)

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<trycatch property="foo"> <try> <fail>Tada!</fail> </try>
<catch> <echo>In catch.</echo> </catch>
<finally> <echo>In finally.</echo> </finally> </trycatch>
<echo>As property: ${foo}</echo>

sect1.title: TstampTask
sect1.para: Sets the DSTAMP, TSTAMP, and TODAY properties in the current project. By default, the DSTAMP property is in the format "%Y%m%d", TSTAMP is in the format "%H%M", and TODAY is in the format "%B %d %Y". Use the nested <format> element to specify a different format.

These properties can be used in the build-file, for instance, to create time-stamped filenames, or used to replace placeholder tags inside documents to indicate, for example, the release date. The best place for this task is probably in an initialization target.

row.entry: Prefix used for all properties set.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <tstamp/>
sect2.para: sets the standard DSTAMP, TSTAMP, and TODAY properties according to the default formats.
sect2.programlisting: <tstamp> <format property="DATE" pattern="%c" locale="nl_NL"/> </tstamp>
sect2.para: sets the standard properties as well as the property DATE with the date/time pattern "%c" using the Dutch locale.
sect2.programlisting: <tstamp prefix="start"/>
sect2.para: sets three properties with the standard formats, prefixed with "start.": start.DSTAMP, start.TSTAMP, and start.TODAY.

listitem.para: The Tstamp task supports a <format> nested element that allows a property to be set to the current date and time in a given format. The date/time patterns are as defined in the PHP strftime() function.

row.entry: The property to receive the date/time string in the given pattern.
The date/time pattern to be used. The values are as defined by the PHP strftime() function.
The locale used to create date/time string. For more information see the PHP setlocale() function.

sect1.title: TypedefTask
sect1.para: With the TypedefTask you can import a user type into your buildfile.

row.entry: The path to the class that defines the type class.
The name the type is available as after importing. If you specify "cproject", for example, you can access the type imported here with <cproject>.
The classpath to use when including classes. This is added to PHP's include_path.
Reference to classpath to use when including classes. This is added to PHP's include_path.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <!-- Includes the Type named "CustomProject" and makes it available by <cproject> --> <typedef classname="user.types.CustomProject" name="cproject" />

sect1.title: UpToDateTask
sect1.para: UpToDateTask tests if a file is newer than another file or files and sets a property if it is. This is a common way to avoid, possibly time consuming, creation of a target if none of the files/resources it depends on have changed.

row.entry: Name of the property that is to be set
The value the property is to be set to
The file to check against target file(s)
The file for which we want to determine the status

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <uptodate property="propelBuild.notRequired" targetfile="${deploy}/propelClasses.tgz" > <fileset dir="${src}/propel"> <include="**/*.php"/> </fileset> </uptodate>
sect2.para: The above example sets the property propelBuild.notRequired to true if the ${deploy}/propelClasses.tgz file is more up-to-date than any of the PHP class files in the ${src}/propel directory.
sect2.programlisting: <target name="CompileTarget"> <uptodate property="target.uptodate" targetfile="main"> <fileset refid="sources"/> </uptodate> <if> <not><isset property="target.uptodate"/></not> <then> <!-- Some commands to update the target ... --> </then> </if> </target>
sect2.para: The above example shows a common use when doing a "compile" type target where a single target depends on other source files. In this case the commands to update the target (whatever they are) are only run if any of the source files are more up to date than the target.

sect1.title: WaitForTask
sect1.para: Wait for a condition to become true or a timeout, whichever comes first.

row.entry: Set the maximum length of time to wait in units
Set the max wait time unit. Must be one of "week","day", "hour", "minute", "second", "millisecond"
Set the time between each check
Set the check every time unit. Must be one of "week","day", "hour", "minute", "second", "millisecond"
Name of the property to set after a timeout.

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.para: Wait for a maximum of ten seconds for the file "ready" to appear.
sect2.programlisting: <waitfor maxwaitunit="second" maxwait="10"> <available file="ready"/> </waitfor>

sect2.title: Supported Nested Tags
sect2.para: All conditionals including and, or, not etc.

sect1.title: XsltTask
sect1.para: With XsltTask, you can run a XSLT transformation on an XML file. Actually, XsltTask extends CopyTask, so you can use all the elements allowed there.

XsltTask is implemented by means of the XsltFlter and hence relies on PHP5 XSLT support via (libxslt) which must be available in php5. The XsltTask is equivalent to running command line xsltproc since that is a frontend for libxslt.

row.entry: The path where the Xslt file is located
Whether to resolve entities in the XML document. (see this link for details)
Whether to resolve entities in the stylesheet.

sect1.para: Note: You can also use all the attributes available for .

sect2.title: Examples
sect2.programlisting: <!-- Transform docbook with an imaginary XSLT file --> <xslt todir="/srv/docs/phing" style="dbk2html.xslt" > <fileset dir="."> <include name="**/*.xml" /> </fileset> </xslt>

sect2.title: Supported Nested Elements
sect2.para: Note: You can use all the elements also available for .
Additionally, you can use <param> tags with a name and a expression (or value alias) attribute. These parameters are then available from within the xsl style sheet.
